results.title: Exploding cities
results.creator_credit: Tina Viljoen, Barrie Howells and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: At the beginning of this century earth was still a rural planet. By the year 2000, two out of three of us will be living in cities. This film examines the causes of this massive migration, the terrible poverty that ensues, and what steps are being taken in some cities in the developing world to cope with the great influx of people. It also notes attempts made by some countries to deal with the problem, e.g. sites and services programs in Senegal and Pakistan, self-help construction projects in Colombia, and house upgrading schemes in Zambia. Voice and narration by Bronwyn Drainie.

results.title: Expectations - a Story about Stress (Captioned)
results.brief_description: This program aims to help pre-adolescents recognise and deal with stress which, according to experts, is the underlying cause of 75% of all illness and disease among children. The video follows the stories of two children, both gymnasts in the school team trying to cope with the expectations and pressures of parents. One child is pushed to perform to the exclusion of all else, and the other child has conflicting demands placed on her.

results.title: Expedition to Franklin Island
results.brief_description: Describes an expedition organized by Marineland of South Australia to Franklin Island in 1974. The party, which included experienced field naturalists, divers and photographers, observed and recorded the behaviour of aquatic and land animals. Credits include: script and edited by Douglas Steen; photographed by Peter George, Peter Caprioli, Igo Oak, Doug Seaton; sound by Ray Swaby, Norman Robinson; commentary by Roger Caldwell.

results.title: Exotica
results.creator_credit: Atom Egoyan, Camelia Frieberg and Ego Film Arts
results.brief_description: Considered one of Canadian director Atom Egoyan’s best moments, this film focuses on the lives of individuals as they revolve, in mysterious guises, around The Exotica, an erotic dance club. Taking the idea of the strip tease, and the voyeurism it plays to, Egoyan slowly reveals, in layers, how the lives we are watching on screen are all connected by a singular tragedy from the past. The ultimate truth of this event being saved right up to the very last scene. Cast includes Mia Kirshner and Egoyan regulars Elias Koteas, Arsinee Khanjian, Bruce Greenwood, Don McKellar and Sarah Polley. (Awards: Winner of the International Critics’ Prize Cannes Film Festival 1994)

results.title: Exiles of love
results.creator_credit: Toby Kalitowski, Greater London Arts and 4BC
results.brief_description: Inspired by the life and works of Jean Genet, this short video includes interviews with four contemporary gay film-makers/writers - Derek Jarman, Neil Bartlett, Constantine Giannaris and Robert Chevara - to investigate the pleasure, the danger, the joy and fear involved in homosexual love and sex. Interspersed with the interviews are scenes set in a prison: gay romanticism and eroticism are linked to a social history of sexual repression and oppression.

results.title: Exercise Musk-ox
results.creator_credit: E Scythes, Douglas Wilkinson, Robert Anderson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A journey of scientific exploration through Canada’s north. Members of the Canadian Army, with snowmobiles and amphibious weasel, made a great winter trek over country never before travelled by motor vehicle. The expedition took detailed weather observations, corrected maps, studied the mobility of snow vehicles, and coped with the weather. Through human skill and endurance the frontier of the north was pushed back, showing its rich promise for the future.

results.title: Everyone says I love you
results.creator_credit: Woody Allen, Robert Greenhut, Jack Rollins, Charles H. Joffe, Sweetland Films BV, Miramax Films, Magnolia Productions and Buena Vista Pictures
results.brief_description: This story of a very well off family living in New York takes the audience on a journey through their daily lives, highlighting the high and lows. The basic family set-up involves the two parents, Bob (Alan Alda) and Steffi (Goldie Hawn), four daughters, a son, a grandfather, and Joe (Woody Allen) - Steffi’s ex-husband. Joe is still very much a part of the family and regularly visits from his home in Paris. Joe seems to have had an endless array of failed relationships, and continuously pines for his ex-lovers. Meanwhile, the eldest daughter, Skylar (Drew Barrymore) is deeply in love with Holden (Edward Norton). Music and an ensemble performance drive the intertwined love stories, which revolve around the members of an extended blended family. The story structure is almost a dance of life that continuously circles around in a cycle of love found, lost, and then found again. The disparate story elements are unified by the use of the narrator DJ (Natasha Lyonne), who is the college-age daughter of Steffi by a previous marriage to Joe. Like almost everyone else in the film, DJ is a romantic at heart who seems to be always falling in and out of love. In addition to narrating, she acts as cupid in helping Joe meet Von (Julia Roberts), a woman he has fallen in love with at first sight. All the principal actors are given at least one song, and with the exception of Drew Barrymore, do their own singing rather than have the voice of a professional singer dubbed in.

results.title: Everynight...everynight
results.brief_description: Ray Mooney wrote and produced his stage play which put life in H Divsion Pentridge under the microscope. It is shot in black and white; the gritty nature of which underpins the brutality and bleakness of the prison and its inmates. Dale, a remand prisoner and notorious hitman, is thrown into H Division where he is subjected to beatings, relentless mind games and mental cruelty at the hands of the warders led by Berriman. Despite the efforts to break his spirit, Dale becomes a law unto himself in order to survive. This film is an indictment of systems. Systems which are open to abuse, to corruption; systems where police can behave like criminals and get away with it. Systems which can alienate and deprive people of their dignity to the extent that violence is a power seeking device from men who have never known influence or affluence. Stars: David Field, Bill Hunter, Robert Morgan. Festivals and Awards: Nominated Best Director (Alkinos Tsilimidos), Best Adapted Screenplay (Ray Mooney and Alkinos Tsilimidos), AFI Awards, 1994; Jury Prize, Best First Film, Montreal Film Festival, 1994; Official Selection, Venice Film Festival, 1994.
